trans-unit.source: Displays a message window, also known as a dialog box, which presents a message to the user.
It is a modal window, blocking other actions in the application until the user closes it.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox"></xref> can contain text, buttons, and symbols that inform and instruct the user.
You cannot create a new instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox> class.
To display a message box, call the `static` method <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
The title, message, buttons, and icons displayed in the message box are determined by parameters that you pass to this method.
Displays a message box with specified text.
By default, the message box displays an **OK** button.
The message box does not contain a caption in the title.
The text to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
Displays a message box with the specified text, caption, buttons, icon, default button, options, and Help button, using the specified Help file and Help keyword.
A message box is a modal dialog box, which means no input (keyboard or mouse click) can occur except to objects on the modal form.
The program must hide or close a modal form (typically in response to some user action) before input to another form can occur.
You can use the `owner` parameter to specify a particular object, which implements the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window> interface, that will serve as the dialog box's top-level owner.
When the user clicks the Help button, the Help file specified in the `helpFilePath` parameter is opened and the Help keyword topic identified by the `keyword` parameter is displayed.
The form that owns the message box (or the active form) also receives the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.HelpRequested> event.
An implementation of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window"></xref> that will own the modal dialog box.
The text to display in the message box.
The text to display in the title bar of the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxButtons"></xref> values that specifies which buttons to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxIcon"></xref> values that specifies which icon to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxDefaultButton"></xref> values that specifies the default button for the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxOptions"></xref> values that specifies which display and association options will be used for the message box.
You may pass in 0 if you wish to use the defaults.
The path and name of the Help file to display when the user clicks the Help button.
The Help keyword to display when the user clicks the Help button.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
buttons is not a member of .
-or-
icon is not a member of .
-or-
The defaultButton specified is not a member of .
An attempt was made to display the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox"></xref> in a process that is not running in User Interactive mode.
This is specified by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation.UserInteractive"></xref> property.
options specified both and .
-or-
buttons specified an invalid combination of .
Displays a message box with the specified text, caption, buttons, icon, default button, options, and Help button, using the specified Help file, `HelpNavigator`, and Help topic.
A message box is a modal dialog box, which means no input (keyboard or mouse click) can occur except to objects on the modal form.
The program must hide or close a modal form (typically in response to some user action) before input to another form can occur.
When the user clicks the Help button, the Help file specified in the `helpFilePath` parameter is opened and the Help content identified by the `navigator` parameter is displayed.
The form that owns the message box (or the active form) also receives the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.HelpRequested> event.
Compiled help files provide table of contents, index, search, and keyword links in pages.

You can use the following values for `navigator`: <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.TableOfContents>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Find>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Index>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic>.
You can use `param` to provide further refinement of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic> command.

If the value specified in the `navigator` parameter is <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.TableOfContents>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Index>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Find>, this value should be `null`.
If the `navigator` parameter references <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic>, this value should reference an object that contains the numeric value of the topic to display.
The `helpFilePath` parameter can be of the form C:\path\sample.chm or /folder/file.htm.
The text to display in the message box.
The text to display in the title bar of the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxButtons"></xref> values that specifies which buttons to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxIcon"></xref> values that specifies which icon to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxDefaultButton"></xref> values that specifies the default button for the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxOptions"></xref> values that specifies which display and association options will be used for the message box.
You may pass in 0 if you wish to use the defaults.
The path and name of the Help file to display when the user clicks the Help button.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator"></xref> values.
The numeric ID of the Help topic to display when the user clicks the Help button.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
buttons is not a member of .
-or-
icon is not a member of .
-or-
The defaultButton specified is not a member of .
An attempt was made to display the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox"></xref> in a process that is not running in User Interactive mode.
This is specified by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation.UserInteractive"></xref> property.
options specified both and .
-or-
buttons specified an invalid combination of .
Displays a message box with the specified text, caption, buttons, icon, default button, options, and Help button, using the specified Help file.
A message box is a modal dialog box, which means no input (keyboard or mouse click) can occur except to objects on the modal form.
The program must hide or close a modal form (typically in response to some user action) before input to another form can occur.

You can use the `owner` parameter to specify a particular object, which implements the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window> interface, that will serve as the dialog box's top-level window and owner.
When the user clicks the Help button, the Help file specified in the `helpFilePath` parameter is opened.
The form that owns the message box (or the active form) also receives the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.HelpRequested> event.
The `helpFilePath` parameter can be of the form C:\path\sample.chm or /folder/file.htm.

One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxOptions"></xref> values that specifies which display and association options will be used for the message box.
You may pass in 0 if you wish to use the defaults.
The path and name of the Help file to display when the user clicks the Help button.

This is specified by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation.UserInteractive"></xref> property.
Displays a message box in front of the specified object and with the specified text.

You can use the `owner` parameter to specify a particular object, which implements the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window> interface, that will serve as the dialog box's top-level window and owner.
A message box is a modal dialog box, which means no input (keyboard or mouse click) can occur except to objects on the modal form.
The program must hide or close a modal form (typically in response to some user action) before input to another form can occur.
By default, the message box displays an **OK** button.
The message box does not contain a caption in the title.
An implementation of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window"></xref> that will own the modal dialog box.
The text to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
Displays a message box with specified text and caption.
By default, the message box displays an **OK** button.
The text to display in the message box.
The text to display in the title bar of the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
Displays a message box with the specified text, caption, buttons, icon, default button, and options.
You can have a maximum of three buttons on the message box.
The text to display in the message box.
The text to display in the title bar of the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxButtons"></xref> values that specifies which buttons to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxIcon"></xref> values that specifies which icon to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxDefaultButton"></xref> values that specifies the default button for the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxOptions"></xref> values that specifies which display and association options will be used for the message box.
You may pass in 0 if you wish to use the defaults.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.

An attempt was made to display the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox"></xref> in a process that is not running in User Interactive mode.
This is specified by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.SystemInformation.UserInteractive"></xref> property.

Displays a message box with the specified text, caption, buttons, icon, default button, options, and Help button, using the specified Help file, `HelpNavigator`, and Help topic.
A message box is a modal dialog box, which means no input (keyboard or mouse click) can occur except to objects on the modal form.
The program must hide or close a modal form (typically in response to some user action) before input to another form can occur.

You can use the `owner` parameter to specify a particular object, which implements the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window> interface, that will serve as the dialog box's top-level window and owner.
When the user clicks the Help button, the Help file specified in the `helpFilePath` parameter is opened and the Help content identified by the `navigator` parameter is displayed.
The form that owns the message box (or the active form) also receives the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.HelpRequested> event.
Compiled help files provide table of contents, index, search, and keyword links in pages.

You can use the following values for `navigator`: <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.TableOfContents>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Find>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Index>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic>.
You can use `param` to provide further refinement of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic> command.

If the value specified in the `navigator` parameter is <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.TableOfContents>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Index>, or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Find>, this value should be `null`.
If the `navigator` parameter references <xref:System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator.Topic>, this value should reference an object that contains the numeric value of the topic to display.
The `helpFilePath` parameter can be of the form C:\path\sample.chm or /folder/file.htm.
An implementation of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.IWin32Window"></xref> that will own the modal dialog box.
The text to display in the message box.
The text to display in the title bar of the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxButtons"></xref> values that specifies which buttons to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxIcon"></xref> values that specifies which icon to display in the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxDefaultButton"></xref> values that specifies the default button for the message box.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MessageBoxOptions"></xref> values that specifies which display and association options will be used for the message box.
You may pass in 0 if you wish to use the defaults.
The path and name of the Help file to display when the user clicks the Help button.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.HelpNavigator"></xref> values.
The numeric ID of the Help topic to display when the user clicks the Help button.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
